docs.lead_paragraph: The past two weeks have not been good ones for George W. Bush. Even before the news emerged that the indispensable Dick Cheney needed more work done on his heart, a series of public opinion polls was giving the president agita.

headline.main: The Message in the Sinking Polls

docs.abstract: Bob Herbert Op-Ed column examines Pres Bush's decline in polls; says Bush does not seem vigorously engaged in very tough job of being president--perception that is hurting him (M)
docs.snippet: The past two weeks have not been good ones for George W. Bush.    Even before the news emerged that the indispensable Dick Cheney needed more work done on his heart, a series of public opinion polls was giving the president agita.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The older women with jobs and benefits who are choosing to delay their retirements are the fortunate ones (front page, June 26). What percentage of the 43 million Americans who have no medical insurance at all are in this age group? While elected officials and the news media devote time and space to patients' rights for those who have health insurance, those without any have become the invisible Americans -- a formidable voting bloc, if any candidate cared.
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    The older women with jobs and benefits who are choosing to delay their retirements are the fortunate ones (front page, June 26). What percentage of the 43 million Americans who have no medical insurance at all are in this age group?...

docs.lead_paragraph: The backlash against managed health care that pushed a patients' bill of rights to the top of the political agenda in Washington has already forced important changes in medical care for millions of Americans. Whatever the fate of the patients' measure passed by the Senate late Friday -- and it still faces passage by the House and a possible veto by President Bush -- managed care is evolving under pressure from doctors, patients, consumer advocates and employers.

headline.main: A CHANGING WORLD IS FORCING CHANGES ON MANAGED CARE

docs.snippet: The backlash against managed health care that pushed a patients' bill of rights to the top of the political agenda in Washington has already forced important changes in medical care for millions of Americans.    Whatever the fate of the patients'...

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: In referring to the recent federal court decision concerning contraception coverage in health insurance plans, a June 26 letter writer asserts that federal law does not broadly exempt ''employers and insurers who invoke a religious objection to contraception.'' In fact, the courts have yet to rule on the issue of whether religious employers may be exempt from such mandates. The federal law in question includes a religious exemption clause. I disagree with the implication that the bill recently passed by the State Senate, which includes conscience protection for religious employers, would not pass muster in federal courts.

docs.lead_paragraph: Doctors successfully implanted a sophisticated pacemaker and defibrillator in Vice President Dick Cheney's chest today, his medical team said. It was the third significant cardiac procedure Mr. Cheney has undergone since his election as vice president. In less than two hours, while Mr. Cheney slept under mild sedation, his doctors concluded that his heart was susceptible to abnormal, rapid heartbeats and installed the device as what they and Mr. Cheney called ''an insurance policy.''

headline.main: CHENEY GETS HEART DEVICE AND DECLARES, 'I FEEL GOOD'

docs.abstract: Doctors at George Washington University Medical Center implant sophisticated pacemaker and defibrillator into Vice Pres Dick Cheney's chest, third significant cardiac procedure he has undergone since taking office; device is described as 'insurance policy' because Cheney's heart is susceptible to abnormal, rapid heartbeats; Cheney leaves hospital hours later, saying 'I feel good'; Pres Bush predicts Cheney will be at work when week begins; cardiologist Jonathan S Reiner explains; photos; device under skin near collarbone responds to irregularity by sending small electrical jolt to heart, acting both as traditional pacemaker but also sa miniature defibrillator that can interrupt potentially fatal rapid heartbeats before they are fatal; Reiner insists Cheney's 'overall condition' is stable despite long history of heart disease (M)

byline.original: By DAVID E. SANGER and LAWRENCE K. ALTMAN

docs.lead_paragraph: Union organizers are turning their attention to upscale food stores, like the Jefferson Market, Balducci's, Gourmet Garage and Dean & Deluca, pressing for better benefits for their workers. At the 72-year-old Jefferson Market, on the Avenue of Americas near 10th Street, more than 200 labor advocates showed up on June 14 to protest what one placard described as ''Upscale prices, bargain basement benefits.''

headline.main: Unions Go Organizing in the Aisles of Mangoes and Mesclun

docs.lead_paragraph: REMEMBER the scene in ''Gone With the Wind'' where Scarlett and Melanie huddle in a horse-drawn buggy at the Atlanta train station, frantically scouring the latest list of Civil War dead? Ashley! Ashley! Would his name be there? Well, fiddle-de-dee, I sure can relate.

headline.main: Who Died? Me, but Fiddle-de-dee, My Chin Is Up

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Your June 24 front-page article about living organ donation once again raises the question of why we, as a society, will not take the steps necessary to increase cadaveric organ donation.

headline.main: For the Dying, a New Lease on Life

docs.abstract: J Daniel Ballard letter on ways to increase cadaveric organ donation (S)
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Your June 24 front-page article about living organ donation once again raises the question of why we, as a society, will not take the steps necessary to increase cadaveric organ donation.

docs.lead_paragraph: Henry Strongin Goldberg was the first to arrive in Minneapolis. His parents decorated his room on the fourth floor of the Fairview-University Medical Center with his inflatable Batman chair, two Michael Jordan posters, a Fisher-Price basketball hoop and a punching bag hanging from the curtain rod over the bed. They took turns sleeping (or not) in his room for more than a month. It was too risky for his little brother to visit, but there was a playground across the courtyard, and if Henry, who was 4, stood at the window and Jack, who was 3, climbed to the top of the slide, the boys could wave to each other. Henry had lost his hair by the time 6-year-old Molly Nash moved in down the hall on the bone-marrow transplant unit. Soon she, too, was bald. The two children had always looked alike, just as all children with this type of Fanconi anemia look alike, with their small faces and small eyes and bodies that are tiny for their age. The ''Fanconi face'' is one more reminder of the claim of the disease. Over time, Fanconi children also come to sound alike, with a deep, mechanical note in their voices, the result of the androgens they take to keep the illness at bay. Once their scalps were bare, Henry and Molly looked nearly identical. But there was one invisible difference between them -- a difference that could mean everything.
docs.abstract: Lisa Belkin article on desperate, high-tech effort by two couples to save children born with Franconi's anemia, which causes bone marrow failure, eventually resulting in leukemia and other forms of cancer; they used in-vitro fertilization and genetic screening to hasten process of producing siblings for their stricken children who would not have disease but whose cord blood would be perfect match for bone marrow transplants; Lisa and Jack Nash succeeded in producing such a child, and subsequent transplant gives their first child, Molly, an excellent chance of survival; Laurie Strongin and Allen Goldberg were not successful, and their son, Henry, received his marrow from anonymous donor; their story raises ethical questions about genetic screening of the unborn and breeding children for 'spare parts'; photo (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York. Senate 1. Patients' Rights: Vote to send a Democratic bill to define patients' rights back to committee to be reviewed. Rejected 61 to 39 on Tuesday. 2. Patients' Rights: Vote on an amendment to a Democratic bill to define patients' rights that would provide employers with complete immunity against lawsuits by employees who challenge the denial of their claims for health benefits. Rejected 57 to 43 on Tuesday.
docs.abstract: Senate roll call (NY-NJ-Conn) vote on six amendments to define patients' rights; vote to send bill back to committee is rejected 6-39; vote that would provide employers with immunity against lawsuits by employees is rejected 57-43; vote that would bar lawsuits against employers with 50 or fewer employees is rejected 53-45; vote to kill amendment that would allow states to enforce their own standard under existing state laws is approved 53-44; vote on amendment that state law must 'substantially comply' with federal insurance standards is approved 64-36; vote that says employers can avoid liability for denial of medical claims by using outside entity for decision making is approved 96-4; House of Representatives roll call vote on amendment to spending bill for Dept of Transportation that would prohibit Mexican trucks from using highways in US beyond 20 miles of border is approved 285-143; vote on amendment to bill that would allocate $23.7 billion for energy and water development projects in Great Lakes is approved 265-157 (M)
